LONDON (AP) — Billy Bonds, the former West Ham United player and manager described as one of soccer’s “greatest competitors,” has died. He was 79. His death was confirmed in a statement by his family via West Ham on Sunday. The Premier League club said Bonds “passed away peacefully” on Sunday morning. Former West Ham captain Bonds was the longest-serving player in the club’s history, making 799 appearances over a 21-year spell. He won two FA Cups before retiring at the age of 41. He managed West Ham from 1990-94. “Dad loved West Ham United and its wonderful supporters with all his heart and...
